Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 02:22PM - edited Sep 28, 2011 02:27PM by alaskadiana My experience was very similar to GiGiL's, almost line for line.  And, yes, Xanax really helped.  It took the cutting edge off the fear.  And as far as being cranky, I think this experience very suddenly reminds you what is important in life, and then all the little BS gets really irritating.  Coworkers and others who aren't supportive can also remind you that it may be time to "weed the garden of your life," if you know what I mean.  Some folks are keepers and some aren't.  But some folks mean well and just say the wrong things.  They think they can take away your fear by telling you why you shouldn't feel it, but that's wrong, even if well-intended.  If I can make a couple suggestions ... after your meds, etc. wear off be sure to support your affected breast (with your arm) if you're on bumpy roads.  We had to drive 3 hours home the day after my surgery (Alaska) and we hit several potholes that made me cry -- and I don't cry easily!  My husband started driving around every pothole (and that was kind of funny) but it was worth it!  2nd, while you are healing, wear a bra that ensures you have no tension whatsoever on your incision.  The less tension you put on it while you heal, the thinner the scar will be.  Just the nature of our breasts trying to hang downward can be enough to make some scars get a little wider.  I kept "my Girl" well lifted for a couple months and my scar is so thin it's barely noticeable.  And you know what?  I don't hate my scar; it's my secret, hidden badge of courage, and reminds me that I walked through this. And as far a hubbies go, there was some awesome advice given to me in the last few days by folks commenting on "Scared, alone, waiting for results."  We have some really cool, insightful women on this site; and their comments helped lower my fears by a HUGE amount (while waiting for biopsy results), esp. in wee hours when things got really scary.  So KNOW that you have lots of folks to help see you through -- it's a whole crowd of support!
Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 01:54PM alaskadiana wrote: T, she's right call your dr; and if it's too late in the day, call either the nurse help line of the hospital where your surgery was or the ER. You sound dehydrated, but if you are vomiting, it will only get worse.  Yes, some folks vomit after anesthesia, but if you're peeing less and thirsty you need some supplemental fluids.  Hope you feel better soon!  If you are taking anything for pain sometimes that can make people vomit, esp. codeine.
Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

Posts.Content: alaskadiana wrote: Funny, after my Friday biopsies I was able to put the brakes on being scared all weekend, but now that it's Monday I woke up terrified.  My husband flew out of town last night and I don't have any close friends in this state, so I'm alone and scared.  Radiologist did 4 biopsies on a "new density" that showed up on mammo/ultrasound on Friday, right at my old surgical/radiation site.  She also inserted a marker clip "just in case" for my surgeon.  Sigh.  Wish I could calm myself.  Feel like a woose.  My husband was a little irritated yesterday that I couldn't be more positive that this is nothing, even though I was calm most of the weekend (with the occasional "OMG" moment).  Sigh again.  Anyone out there? Dx 2/28/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/10 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 10:41AM - edited Sep 26, 2011 10:43AM by alaskadiana You're right about my husband's frustration coming out.  He said later he was just trying to find a way to make me less scared, hoping he could "talk me out of it."  And don't forget, ignorance isn't bliss ... denial is bliss!!!  And he has a lot of denial.  [I figure, if you're ignorant about something you could be blindsided, and that's bad; but if you HAVE the info you need and CHOOSE denial, then you're in a slightly better position.]  So, inside he knows what's going on, but chooses to believe everything will turn out fine.  Sigh!  And BTW, I now feel like less of a woose.  Thx.
Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 11:43AM alaskadiana wrote: Wow, this is an amazing source of support!!!  Women rock, don't we?  No doubt, a huge and very cool sisterhood!  And BTW, Adey, ... I was REALLY surprised to hear from you ... as Adey was the name of my imaginary childhood friend when I was five!!!!  LOL big time!   Glad you all liked the peckergram idea.  Quite a visual, isn't it?
Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 08:12PM - edited Sep 26, 2011 08:13PM by alaskadiana Thanks everybody.  It was a lonnng day, but it's after 5 now and no call.  My radiologist (that I really love, she's AMAZING) said Monday, maybe Tuesday, so I hope I don't have to wait as long as some of you have.  In this past year of BC, I have been amazed and honored at the awesome women out there who've dealt with this and voluntarily give of their time, info and support to help another woman affected by BC ... total strangers!!!  It's incredible.  And then, the link continues to another woman and another, exponentially!!  It truly is like a big club, that no one wants to be in, ... but when you need it, it's there. Like me this morning when I was soooo scared.  Your posts really, REALLY helped.  Thanks from my heart.
Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 01:45PM alaskadiana wrote: HEY,  EVERYBODY ---  IT'S GOOD, IT'S GOOD, IT'S ALL GOOD!!!  The biopsies showed it was some fibrosing from the radiation, NOT CANCER.  YIPPPPPPPEEEEEEE!!!!!!  [Insert happy, happy dance here.]   I JUST found out ... and BTW, I also found out you CAN laugh, cry and jump up and down at the same time!!!!!!!!!!!  (-:
Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

I was just saying to the mammo tech on Friday that if men had to get "peckergrams" every year and get squeezed between two plates like we do, the technology would change SO fast and become so much more comfortable!!  My site is so high on my chest that we have to do some pretty amazing contortions and hard squeezes to try to get my surgical site into the picture.  I always end up sore and bruised.  Will surely post when I hear anything.  Thanks to EVERYONE!

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 02:33AM - edited Sep 27, 2011 02:35AM by alaskadiana Wow, Mostlymom, your timing is excellent.  I forgot how much nights can suck when you're waiting for a diagnosis, with hubby out of town.  You're right, he's likely frustrated that he can't "fix" this.  I like your idea to ask him to "hold me when I cry, listen when I have to talk, & give me lots of hugs."  That'll give him a concrete plan of action; he is very supportive.  No wonder you've been married 49 years (although you don't look it!).   Thanks for logging on this late ... right when I felt extra scared again.  THANK YOU.  [Big hug.]  I don't know where Thompson Park is/was, will ask my husband, as he was raised here and I've only been in Alaska 21 years.  Is it on the Spur?

Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 01:47PM alaskadiana wrote: Waiting through any of this is the hardest part.  The actual procedure is pretty brief, and mine didn't hurt at all, even the local was easy.  It is nerve wracking and hard not to think about it, but a DVD and a glass of wine work sometimes for me.  You'll walk through this and you'll be able to tell someone else someday how you got through it, and it will help them.  But for now, try to stay occupied and keep on posting!  Let us know how it turns out.
